bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, September 2, 1942

div1.p: Kellogg discusses his meeting with Siler. He informs Hench that Lawrence Reed was honored to personally present Hench's application for an army commission.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, September 2, 1942
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
41 EAST 42ND STREET
NEW YORK, N.Y.
September 2, 1942
Dear Phil,
div1.p:
Under separate cover I am sending you a copy of the
american Exporter (in Spanish) which carries a picture and story
on “Conquerors of Yellow Fever” on page 38.

I spent an evening last week with Col. Siler, as I
wrote you. He is now president of Gorgas Institute and back in
active service, being a member of the two boards in some way
associated with the Surgeon General's office. He was most co-
operative and said that he would like to be of help to the mag-
azine (ARMY DOCTOR) but by necessity of his present active duty
he would have to consult the Surgeon General'personally. I don't
know just what the outcome will be but my prognosis is that they
will recommend someone less active than Col. Siler. What we really
need on the job is a youngman.

I have pictures of the Reeds and the Keans which I will
send you at an early date. I had cocktails with Gen. Reed Saturday
afternoon and he asked me to forward the following message.

When the recommendations for your commission came up to
the Craig board in the War Department it just happened that your
application came into Gen. Reed's hands. As you may know, there are
six generals on this Board who pass on all commissions and promo-
tions in the army with the possible exceptions of those of the 2nd
lieutenant. Gen. Reed wanted me to tell you that he told the Board
that he was both happy and honored to present your application for
the comission and that he had the privilege of telling them quite
a story about your research on the “Yellow Fever” project. It goes
without saying that your commission was passed unanimously by the
Board.

I was pleasantly surprised with Gen. Reed as he could
pass for being considerably younger than the 64 years he admits
and he is an all around good fellow. The way he feels about you
is that if someone will propose that you be made a general at the
end of six months I don't think you will encounter any obstacles
whatsoever. If I were you, I would bear that in mind. Reed is
certainly in a key position.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg GAK:L
Lieut. Col. Philip S. Hench
Station Hospital, Camp Carson
Colorado Springs, Colorado
Enc-1
